                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                        <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>

                            </gmd:organisationName>
                            <gmd:role>
                                <gmd:CI_RoleCode
                                        codeList="https://schemas.isotc211.org/19115/-3/cit/1.0/codelists.xml#CI_RoleCode"
                                        codeListValue="author">author

                        </gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                    
                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                        <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>

                                <gco:CharacterString>Lake Winnipeg Foundation</gco:CharacterString>
                            </gmd:organisationName>
                            <gmd:role>
                                <gmd:CI_RoleCode
                                        codeList="https://schemas.isotc211.org/19115/-3/cit/1.0/codelists.xml#CI_RoleCode"
                                        codeListValue="contributor">contributor
                                </gmd:CI_RoleCode>
                            </gmd:role>
                        </gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                </gmd:CI_Citation>
            </gmd:citation>
            <gmd:abstract>
                <gco:CharacterString>The Lake Winnipeg Community-Based Monitoring Network (LWCBMN) is a growing network that engages citizen volunteers to collect water samples across Manitoba using scientifically vetted protocols. Samples are then analyzed in a lab to measure phosphorus concentration and calculate the amount of phosphorus begin exported off our landscapes.

While Lake Winnipeg receives its water from a vast watershed, not all areas of the watershed contribute equal amounts of phosphorus. By sampling frequently at many sites, LWCBMN is able to pinpoint phosphorus hotspots – areas that contribute a disproportionate amount of phosphorus to Lake Winnipeg.

Snow melts, floods and heavy rainfall events are responsible for most of the phosphorus that is flushed from the land into our waterways. Special care is taken by network staff and volunteers to ensure phosphorus runoff is captured during these high-water events. And, because these volunteers live, work or commute near their sampling sites, LWCBMN can quickly mobilize citizen scientists to collect samples when it matters most.</gco:CharacterString>
            </gmd:abstract>

                            </gmd:northBoundLatitude>
                        </gmd:EX_GeographicBoundingBox>
                    </gmd:geographicElement>
                    <gmd:temporalElement>
                        <gmd:EX_TemporalExtent>
                            <gmd:extent>

    </gmd:identificationInfo>

keywords_translation_method.fr: Keyword text translated using the Amazon translate service / texte traduit à l'aide du service Amazon translate

name: 10-25976-hxqe-py39
notes:
The Lake Winnipeg Community-Based Monitoring Network (LWCBMN) is a growing network that engages citizen volunteers to collect water samples across Manitoba using scientifically vetted protocols. Samples are then analyzed in a lab to measure phosphorus concentration and calculate the amount of phosphorus begin exported off our landscapes.

While Lake Winnipeg receives its water from a vast watershed, not all areas of the watershed contribute equal amounts of phosphorus. By sampling frequently at many sites, LWCBMN is able to pinpoint phosphorus hotspots – areas that contribute a disproportionate amount of phosphorus to Lake Winnipeg.

Snow melts, floods and heavy rainfall events are responsible for most of the phosphorus that is flushed from the land into our waterways. Special care is taken by network staff and volunteers to ensure phosphorus runoff is captured during these high-water events. And, because these volunteers live, work or commute near their sampling sites, LWCBMN can quickly mobilize citizen scientists to collect samples when it matters most.

notes_translated.en:
The Lake Winnipeg Community-Based Monitoring Network (LWCBMN) is a growing network that engages citizen volunteers to collect water samples across Manitoba using scientifically vetted protocols. Samples are then analyzed in a lab to measure phosphorus concentration and calculate the amount of phosphorus begin exported off our landscapes.

While Lake Winnipeg receives its water from a vast watershed, not all areas of the watershed contribute equal amounts of phosphorus. By sampling frequently at many sites, LWCBMN is able to pinpoint phosphorus hotspots – areas that contribute a disproportionate amount of phosphorus to Lake Winnipeg.

Snow melts, floods and heavy rainfall events are responsible for most of the phosphorus that is flushed from the land into our waterways. Special care is taken by network staff and volunteers to ensure phosphorus runoff is captured during these high-water events. And, because these volunteers live, work or commute near their sampling sites, LWCBMN can quickly mobilize citizen scientists to collect samples when it matters most.
notes_translated.fr:
Le Réseau de surveillance communautaire du lac Winnipeg (LWCBMN) est un réseau en pleine croissance qui fait appel à des citoyens bénévoles pour prélever des échantillons d'eau à travers le Manitoba en utilisant des protocoles scientifiquement approuvés. Les échantillons sont ensuite analysés dans un laboratoire pour mesurer la concentration de phosphore et calculer la quantité de phosphore qui commence à être exportée hors de nos paysages.

Bien que le lac Winnipeg tire son eau d'un vaste bassin versant, toutes les zones du bassin versant ne fournissent pas des quantités égales de phosphore. En échantillonnant fréquemment de nombreux sites, le LWCBMN est en mesure de localiser les points chauds de phosphore, c'est-à-dire des zones qui fournissent une quantité disproportionnée de phosphore dans le lac Winnipeg.

La fonte des neiges, les inondations et les fortes pluies sont à l'origine de la majeure partie du phosphore évacué du sol dans nos cours d'eau. Le personnel du réseau et les bénévoles prennent des précautions particulières pour s'assurer que le phosphore de ruissellement est capté lors de ces périodes de crue. Et comme ces volontaires vivent, travaillent ou font la navette à proximité de leurs sites d'échantillonnage, le LWCBMN peut rapidement mobiliser des scientifiques citoyens pour prélever des échantillons au moment le plus important.

description_translated.en: DataStream is an open access platform for sharing water and sediment quality data.
description_translated.fr: DataStream est une plateforme en libre accès pour partager des données sur la qualité de l'eau et des sédiments.

title: Lake Winnipeg Community-Based Monitoring Network

title_translated.fr: Réseau de surveillance communautaire du lac Winnipeg
